awd_titl_txt: Particles and Strings in the Gravitating and Evolving Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research of Professors Mina Aganagic, Raphael Bousso, and Petr Horava at the University of California, Berkeley.

In the first two decades of the 21st century, we have witnessed an unprecedented convergence of discoveries that are bringing into focus fundamental questions about the origin, structure, and evolution of the Universe.  The new experimental data in particle physics and cosmology are being confronted with theoretical questions:  What is the Universe made of?  How are the puzzles of gravity resolved when gravity is unified with quantum mechanics?  What are the nature and origins of the fundamental constituents of matter, their interactions, and the observed patterns of cosmological structure in the Universe?  Together, experimental discoveries and new theoretical ideas are leading to an effective synthesis of previously disconnected areas of research.  This unprecedented convergence of experimental and theoretical results, which aims to formulate the fundamental laws of nature in one coherent framework, is of utmost importance for the advancement of the national interest because it promotes and advances progress in the natural sciences and in our understanding of the laws of the Universe at scales ranging from the microscopic and subatomic to the cosmological.  In their research, Professors Aganagic, Bousso, and Horava will perform fundamental theoretical research at the crossroads of particle physics, quantum gravity, cosmology, and string theory.  In addition to addressing some of the deepest puzzles about the laws of the Universe, this research is envisioned to have significant broader impacts.  By involving postdocs and students in cutting-edge theoretical research, this research will significantly contribute to the critical training of the next generation of scientists.  This research will also enrich the public domain, with Professors Aganagic, Bousso, and Horava delivering public lectures on the results of this research.   This research will also improve the academic curriculum at UC Berkeley, with new findings being directly integrated into new and existing courses.

More specifically, Professor Aganagic will pursue the study of the refined topological string and gauge theories, the Langlands correspondence, and little string theory.  Professor Bousso will study the interplay between geometry, entropy, gravity, and quantum information, specifically on the quantum-focusing conjecture and the quantum null-energy condition, new area theorems and the cosmological second law, and asymptotic symmetries in relation to the information problem.  Professor Horava will study non-relativistic quantum field theory and quantum gravity and their applications to the puzzles of naturalness in particle phenomenology and cosmology, as well as the connection to the Causal Dynamical Triangulations approach to quantizing gravity.  He also intends to apply methods of non-equilibrium field theory to string and M-theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this Project Outcomes and Findings report, we summarize the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the research performed by this group of co-PIs and their collaborators, which ranges across a wide range of subfields of high-energy theoretical particle physics, including quantum field theory, string theory, quantum gravity, quantum information, cosmology, and the interface between string theory, quantum gravity and pure mathematics.  Under this Award, significant results have been achieved in all these areas; more specifically:

Mina Aganagic made discoveries at the interface between string theory, quantum field theory and mathematics.  String theory predicts existence of a remarkable quantum field theory in six spacetime dimensions, called ``theory X'', whose symmetries include conformal symmetry and extended chiral supersymmetry. The theory is remarkable because it provides a non-perturbative window into quantum field theories in lower dimensions, and provides a unified framework for them. It is also expected to contain insights at the cutting edge of modern mathematics, into the knot categorification program and the geometric Langlands program. The theory is always strongly coupled, which poses a challenge for its quantitative understanding and for extracting its mathematical implications.  Prof. Aganagic initiated a powerful program which changes the focus from theory X to a six-dimensional ``little string theory''.  The little string is a more powerful starting point because its topological defects are more easily understood.  It reduces to theory X when the characteristic string size goes to zero. The physical description of defect theories survives this limit only in exceptional cases, but in those cases one gets a precise new handle on the physics of theory X.These new insights are opening a new area at the intersection of mathematics and physics which may be called "quantum geometric representation theory". The fact that one can study symmetries geometrically using quantum, stringy geometry is crucial. Prof. Aganagic developed the relation between homological mirror symmetry and knot categorification problem, with an algorithmic approach to categorification of quantum group invariants of knots, using Lie algebras and superalgebras.


The research of Raphael Bousso focused on quantum information as a central tool in the quest to unify quantum mechanics and gravitation. His research at Berkeley has been at the forefront of this exciting recent development. Together with his students, they have formulated powerful new conjectures that encompass and extend known results in quantum gravity, including various entropy bounds, a new area law, the Generalized Second Law for Cosmology, and the Quantum Focusing Conjecture, a more powerful generalization of the covariant entropy bound. These conjectures have become discovery tools, revealing fascinating properties of quantum field theory that can be rigorously proven. They obtained the Quantum Null Energy Condition, a lower bound on the energy density of quantum fields, in terms of a derivative of the von Neumann entropy. Recently, Prof. Bousso focused on the new concept of entanglement islands, in quantum gravity and cosmology.  This has become a very active area with many important results which in turn raise fascinating new questions for future research.

Petr Horava's research focused primarily on: (i) string theory out of equilibrium, (ii) topological quantum gravity of the Ricci flow, and (iii) nonrelativistic approach to puzzles of Technical Naturalness in the Standard Model, gravity and cosmology.  First, using methods of the large-N expansion in quantum systems out of equilibrium, a novel and surprising prediction was derived for the expected structure of string perturbation theory in the dual, string-theory description:  The simple topological genus expansion in the sum over string worldsheets is refined in non-equilibrium systems to a triple topological decomposition associated with the so-called Schwinger-Keldysh closed-time contour description of nonequilibrium systems.  This predicted structure is expected to emerge in any string description of nonequilibrium quantum systems, including cosmology.  Secondly, PH's group constructed a novel topological quantum gravity, built around the famous mathematical theory of Ricci flows on Riemannian manifolds (as used by Perelman to prove the Poincare conjecture about three-dimensional manifolds).  This new topological gravity is nonrelativistic in nature, and represents a concrete example of a Horava-Lifshitz-type quantum gravity.  Thirdly, PH further studied how nonrelativitic quantum-gravity concepts of anisotropic space-time scaling alleviate some of the deepest puzzles in modern theoretical physics -- the puzzles of ``technical naturalness'' of various hierarchies, exemplified by the Higgs mass hierarchy puzzle and the puzzle of the smallness of the observed cosmological constant.  PH established that short-distance nonrelativistic scaling provides a handle for novel solutions of these puzzles.  

Throughout the duration of this Award, these co-PIs fully involved a very vibrant group of graduate students and postdoctoral scholars (and even several undergraduate students) in the center of the reported research activities, leading to an exceptionally strong record of advancement of the young researchers' careers.  The results of the work of this group were widely disseminated in  published scientific papers, invited talks at conferences, seminars and schools, and significant public outreach.
